title: Why the Public internet is a bottleneck for blockchain - Austin Federa, co-founder Double Zero

rawLines.text: Hello everyone. Welcome back to
Cointelegraph's live stream right here
at Proof of Talk in Paris. Uh it's been
a fantastic two days here at this
conference, a conference that came
around last year and really made waves
for the high-profile speakers that they
have um and the really great programming
and venue uh right here in the heart of
Paris at the Louv. Um I'm joined today
by a man that I I know quite well. We we
we've spoken many occasions uh always to
do with Salana. Austin Federa, it's
great to have you on the live stream.
Before we get started, if you have any
questions for Austin, please drop them
uh in the comments right here on X or
YouTube, whatever platform you're
watching on, go ahead, fire them away.
We'll we'll we'll pose them to Austin.
He can say yes or no. You you have free
will. Um but it's good to see you again,
man. And um in very different
circumstances. I don't want to talk too
much about Salana, but I've never asked
you since you left. tell us the story
why you left Salana um and what your
your your general experience was there
and uh the story behind that. Yeah, well
thanks for having me. I mean I was with
Salana for 4 years um when I joined
there were I think 30 daily active
programs on the network and no one
really knew what Salana was. It was very
much an underdog. Um and then you know
you fast forward four years later and
the network is one of the most dominant
networks out there. It is the highest
revenue generation network in crypto. um
it's in an incredible place. Um but I
kind of always had a little bit of that
itch to go be a founder and at the same
time I really didn't want to go build
something that was competitive with
Salana or build something that was on
top of Salana, right? It was it was
really like a challenge to think of what
are what are the types of applications
you can build that will really move
crypto forwards a decade and two years.
How do we really get into this place?
We've talked about mainstream adoption
and taking on Trad 5 forever, but the
fundamental core infrastructure isn't
there. And so the real moment for me to
say D0 is worth building and there's a
market here that's worth addressing was
working on the Fire Dancer project and
seeing the fact that we had engineers
working on this project that could build
a validator client that could do a
million transactions per second, but
they couldn't run it on the public
internet. The public internet was just
too slow. And going through this journey
of like what do we do about that? Do we
go the model of dropping the validator
set from 2,000 validators to a 100
validators? Do we try and make everyone
run in the same data center? Like how is
this solved in Tradfi? Because this is
solved in Tradfi, right? But it's
centralized. But it's centralized. So
how do we build it in a decentralized
way? And that was kind of where the idea
for D0ero first kind of, you know, you
get those ideas in your head and you
just some of them stick around for six
months and you're like, okay, this this
is a real thing. I should go find some
people and build a company out of this
and launch a protocol. So, let's talk
about D0ero. Give us the TLDDR. What is
0ero? Uh, how did the idea come to
fruition? Who gave you money to build
it? Why didn't you do it with Salana?
Yeah, give us give us the the details.
So,0ero is a physical fiber
infrastructure network for high
performance distributed systems. And
there's a lot of different things to
break down there. At its core, what
we're building is a parallel network to
the public internet. So, as most people
know, the public internet runs over
fiber cables. Like 99 plus percentage of
all data moving through the internet
doesn't go through satellites or space.
It goes through cables both on the
ground and under the ocean. And
you would think that there is these big
publicly traded internet companies that
use the internet, right? We think of
Facebook, Netflix, Google, Amazon as
internet companies. They're not really
internet companies. Most of the data
they move around the world doesn't run
through the public internet. It runs
through private networks that they run.
And they use the internet for last mile
delivery. But for the most part, all
these big companies, they've gotten to a
scale where the internet no longer meets
the demands that they have. They have to
move too much data. Meta is one of the
biggest investors in fiber
infrastructure in the world. And they
started off first building data centers
and because they couldn't find their
needs in existing data centers. And then
now they build undersea fiber. And
crypto is kind of at that same point
where for us to reach the next level of
scale, we need to be building our own
physical infrastructure as well. That's
a crazy thought. Yeah. I I didn't
actually know that that was the like the
the core bit of that. So I mean does
that mean that zero is actually laying
fiber cables in different so we're not
today. Um, and this is the same way that
all these other companies started doing
this is there are a large amount of
existing fiber infrastructure that are
run by carriers all around the world and
you can take leases on them the same way
you can take a lease on a on a bare
metal server in a data center somewhere.
And so D0ero is comprised of today six
independent contributors and those
entities are ones that either have they
own fiber or they have leases on fiber
and they're contributing that to the
zero network. And so you know on the
public internet today it's an incredible
resource, right? The public internet's
great at what we do on it, but it's not
built for high performance distributed
systems. And so it's not good at that
idea of we need to get data from this
one validator out to the entire rest of
the network and then a different
validator and then a different validator
and then a different validator.
Everything else on the internet is built
for like one big central server talking
to many many many clients. Um and this
is why for years it was really hard to
stream the Super Bowl. Yeah. Why was it
hard to stream the Super Bowl? We've had
live broadcast television for, you know,
60 years at this point. Well, it's
because every time you send out a uh
additional subscriber, that's more data
that you have to send out, right? And
so, one of the big unlocks here is on a
private network, we can use technology
that's not available on the public
internet like multiccast. And multiccast
is what Tradfi uses for pricing feeds,
is how they move data around the world
really efficiently. And we can bring
that to blockchain for the first time.
And this is not like a small performance
improvement. These are 10x to 100x
performance improvements. compared to
the public internet which is pretty
substantial. There's a great question
coming through here from the live stream
and and please do keep them coming
through it. It says why should we or
anyone trust another decentralized
infrastructure when a lot of the other
ones ended up like VC owned or dead? Um
who who's going to be using zero? Well,
I want to start with the first premise
of who do you think owns the internet
today? Do you think it's a bunch of
nonprofit foundations or do you think
it's a bunch of private equity companies
and venture capitalists and uh pension
funds and you know all of the normal
things that own equity companies, right?
There's only actually 21 20 to 21
depends how you count tier one ISPs in
the world. So that means if there's 20
companies that collude together, they
can turn off the internet for everybody.
Yeah. Uh, and also if you look at like
internet to your house, if you were in
the United States, chances are you have
one or maybe two internet service
providers. Europe's a little better, but
all the internet infrastructure in many
countries in Europe is owned by the
government. Yeah. Right. Like uh I
believe in France, all of your fiber is
actually uh run by the government and
then leased out to companies that then
operate ISPs. Um that is a model where
you still have a centralized actor
controlling it. So to get first off the
the premise I think is worth pushing
back on because it's not saying why
would you use a a physical
infrastructure network like0ero compared
to the platonic ideal of how this should
be done. It's what is our benchmark
we're comparing ourselves to. So then
going from there, D0ero has multiple
independent contributors and so we have
that censorship resistance guarantee of
if one provider starts censoring you,
there are other pathways your data can
take to get to the validators and the
places that it needs to go to. Uh the
other thing too is on the public
internet today, you have no guarantee on
traffic. And I don't just mean guarantee
like an SLA of how long it takes your
data to get there, which you don't have.
There's no guarantee that there isn't a
someone in the middle inspecting your
data, looking at it, modifying it,
holding your data back so they can
frontr run you. All of these types of
things you have no guarantees about on
the public internet. But in D0ero, we
can provide that. We know exactly how
long it takes data to get from point A
to point B. And so if there's a a
network link in the middle that is
sometimes holding some people's data
back, maybe to try and frontr run them,
maybe for something else, we can catch
that and we can slash them. And so we
bring the type of cryptoeconomic
security and the sort of idea like the
power of Bitcoin in the early days was
it weaponizes greed to produce positive
sum outcomes. Right? My incentive is to
catch you cheating because it makes me
more money and your incentive is to
catch me cheating because it makes you
more money. And that reciprocal system
we don't have on the internet today.
Yeah. Yeah. I think you answered that
very eloquently. I've got another one
another question here. And this this is
this one just goes as hard.
decentralized infrastructure. It sounds
good, but is double zero just IPFS plus
marketing? What what what's the new
approach here? So, IPFS is a uh first
off, it's a storage network, right? And
so,0ero, we are not a smart contract
network. No one's this is not a new L1
or an L2. It's it's way below the stack
in that. And you know, we don't have any
compute resources or storage resources.
All this is is data delivery and
bandwidth. And so you can think about
this from that from that perspective of
the challenge with most uh alternatives
to centralized web two services today is
they are lower performance and more
expensive.
D0ero is I think the first deepen
network if you want to call it a deep
network. It's not really a deepen
network but that I've come across where
the baseline service is higher than you
can get in web 2. Now, we don't have and
we're not competing with like Tradfi
companies, right? If you look at like
Citadel and Jump, like their
highfrequency trading networks are more
performant than the double zero network,
but we are much more performant than the
public internet. And so, the trade-off
that you're usually asked to make in
crypto is this thing is going to be more
expensive and less performant, but it
has decentralization. And that matters a
ton. I don't want to like downplay that.
that is the entire value of Bitcoin or
Salana or Ethereum. But in D0ero, we are
more performant than the public
internet. And so, plus there's
decentralization, plus there's economic
security behind it. So, if you are a
company that can afford to run fiber all
around the world, you have, you know,
$200 million a year on infrastructure
budget. You're not going to use double
zero. But if you are not that, this is a
very attractive uh solution to you. And
also if you're something like a
blockchain that requires multiple
entities to be involved in running that
network, you're not going to be happy
with one centrally run network anyway.
Yeah. When it when it comes to the this
idea and how it was born, um I've spoken
to obviously to from Salana and he gave
me the Genesis story and and his
experience at Qualcomm and taking a lot
of those ideas and then building out
Salana's infrastructure. Did you have a
similar sort of process like seeing how
Salana does things, how it how its
network runs and then taking that
approach and being like we can do this
in an infrastructure play and
many many different distributed systems
need this kind of infrastructure. Yeah.
I mean I think the the probably better
origin story for this is um one so
there's three co-founders for zero. Uh
Matteo Ward's origin story here is
probably the most relevant. So he
actually thought about building this
back in 2017. Okay. and talked to a few
folks about it. And his background is uh
you know he worked for Global Crossing
back in the day which is the first
company to run fiber all around the
world in the late 90s. Uh he did a bunch
of shortwave work, a bunch of um
microwave tower work, built out fiber
networks across uh Latin America, ran a
carrier business down there and was sort
of thinking if crypto really is the
future like we need it to be running on
this high performance infrastructure.
But in 2017, the fastest thing in the
world was Ethereum, which did about, you
know, 14 to 21 things per second with 30
second block times. And so there really
wasn't a need at that point. But now we
have Salana, Tooi, Apdos, Fast L2s, we
have Hyperlquid, we have all sorts of
networks that now, like for years, the
software was the thing holding
blockchains back. GU wasn't very good in
2017, right? These these networks just
weren't mature enough that speed and
latency mattered. Software is no longer
the problem. The limiting factor for
blockchain scalability today, it's not
how fast you can prove a ZK proof. It's
not how good the code is on a validator
client. It's the public internet. Yeah.
Okay. When it when it comes to rolling
out the infrastructure,
what is the approach here? I mean, like
where are you starting? Are you just
approaching ISPs and and fiber fiber
actual fiber infrastructure companies
and saying, "Hey, let us let us use your
network and run our software basically."
So, as I mentioned before, most of these
companies today are owned by private
equity or they're publicly traded
companies, neither of which is
particularly crypto friendly. And so, we
have found that the early contributors
to the network are trading firms that
already have crypto divisions. And so,
you know, Jump and Galaxy are two
network contributors, uh, which, you
know, makes sense given their other
activities. We also have two venture
capital firms that have actually decided
to build out network capacity as a way
of earning tokens. So distributed global
and rockaway X are doing that as well.
And then we have two companies that
anyone in operating in crypto will know
very well which is Teras switch and
latitude and they're network
contributors as well. And they actually
own and operate uh servers inside of
data centers. And they're one of the
major providers of servers for a bunch
of high performance blockchains out
there today. And so they'd been sort of
slowly eating away at a little bit of
this problem by getting dedicated fiber
between their data centers. But what
they kind of realize is if they
contribute that network capacity to
double zero, we can grow the performance
of the entire validator network. And
that's really the thing is that that
getting a few validators on faster
connections doesn't really help. But the
minute you get most of the validators on
a fast network connection, you can raise
the number of CUS in a Salana block from
50 million to 500 million. You can
shrink block times. You can scale
capacity out even more. And that's where
the sort of idea of accelerating crypto
by a decade over the next two years
comes from. I think it's very possible
that we look forwards in two years and
we see multiple networks running
multiple hundreds of thousands of
transactions not on test nets with you
know limited environments but on
mainetss that are distributed all around
the world. How hard has it been to like
I mean you guys had a great raise. I
think it was 20 28 million at a 400
million valuation initially. Um, was it
easy to sell the idea to some of the the
VCs and and initial investors? Uh, were,
you know, were Tony and Raj some of the
initial investors? Maybe you can chat a
bit about that. Yeah, you know, I was
thinking it was going to be more of a
challenge to get people interested in
this project than it was. Um, this is
the least sexy project in crypto. Uh,
this is physical fiber in the ground.
This is like the stuff that no one gets
like really I thought excited about. Um,
but it turns out that this is a problem
that a lot of people deeply understand
in crypto. And a lot of the best crypto
VCs, they were junior partners or
interns back in the '90s. And so they
saw the first wave of the internet. They
saw the first wave of private networking
come into these businesses and how
transformational it was. You fast
forward, you know, 25 years, 30 years,
now they're the ones making that are GPS
at these funds. And so there's a there's
a part of this where we'd be talking to
some of these folks and it was almost
like the the 25 to 30 year olds didn't
get it as much as the 40-year-olds.
They're like, "Oh, I saw this before."
Like this this reminds me of some of the
work I was doing earlier in my career.
And so we have an incredible group of of
backers on the project and uh it's been
a a real pleasure to work with them on
this. When it's when it's running like a
pure infrastructure play, I mean there's
no token involved or anything like that,
right? What's what's what's the business
model? How does that work? So we are a
token network. Okay. Yes. Um so there
there is a token for0ero. Um and that
token is really integral to aligning
incentives and functionality of the
network. So validators and RPCs and
other sort of uh users of the network on
that perspective pay to operate on it.
Okay. Those rewards um are paid in the
zero token. they're distributed out to
bandwidth contributors um resource
providers and then you know a portion of
those uh fees are also burned um on the
network as well as a civil resistance
mechanism. The really interesting piece
is most of the criticisms of proof
ofstake and deepen networks are that
they reward basically passive existence
and our model doesn't do that. We
actually published a blog post a few
days ago called proof of utility. And
really the model here is we reward
useful connectivity and we reward it
only from the reward pool that's coming
in from from users of the network. So we
don't have crazy inflation on the
network. We don't have sort of passive
existence rewards. It's a similar model
to proof of work in Bitcoin where if you
produce 50% of the hash power, you will
over an average period of time get 50%
of the rewards. If you provide the most
useful network connectivity pathway that
reaches the most stake, you are going to
be rewarded proportionally for that.
Okay. Was it hard to come up with that
sort of a a token incentive structure?
Who who was the brains behind that? Uh I
mean it it's very much a team effort on
this. Um Nihar is our chief economist.
He's been instrumental in helping think
through these problems. Um but it's very
different. You know, you look at a proof
ofstake network and one of the things to
remember is a validator in Singapore is
useful to me in New York. My transaction
can be included in a block that it's
building just fine, assuming, of course,
my data gets there in time. Um,
bandwidth connectivity in Singapore does
me no good if my validator is in New
York. And so we had to think of a model
that was fundamentally
geographically and local aware. Proof
ofstake networks and proof of work
networks, locality does not matter. In a
in a network like zero, local locality
is of paramount importance. Yes, of
course. Yeah. I mean, it's like anything
in the like we we all played a lot of
internet games like I used to live in
South Africa. Yeah. I I played a lot of
World of Warcraft. When I when I logged
in and I was on a European server, I
always had 300 milliseconds of uh you
know, latency because it is what it is.
I've got a few more questions coming in
here. One of these is really
interesting. DeFi Dynamo. Are you
admitting the public internet is already
holding back blockchains? The public
internet is absolutely holding back
blockchains today. Um my my general
thesis here is you have left curve and
you have right curve. And left curve is
the Bitcoin guys. And they're totally
right. You need to be able to validate
blocks on an FM radio broadcast from
space completely offline or we go all
the way to private connectivity. And I
think anything in the middle is uh first
off the internet is holding back
blockchain. The second thing is this the
sort of censorship resistance guarantees
that people think they have on these
networks really don't exist. Like the
internet is quite easy for governments
to censor. Yeah. And that's the weak
part. It's not how many validators you
have. It's not how many client
diversity. Like that all matters as
well. But the fundamental choke point is
if all the OECD countries say no more
Ethereum and they send a letter to your
ISP that says no more Ethereum, what are
you broadcasting your blocks on? Like
you have to go full Bitcoin or or accept
that like we need to push maximum
performance. Um I've got a couple more
coming through. I'm I'm just going to
I'm going to entertain the questions
because they're coming through. So thank
you very much for engaging with us and
sending these questions. Uh, Infra
insider, your validated token sale was
only for accredited investors. Does that
make your infrastructure exclusive and
and not inclusive?
Accredited investor requirements are not
uh something we have any control over.
Um, most countries and most
jurisdictions have some version of an
accredited investor rule. Um, I will say
we were the first uh regulated token
sale that Coin List has done in the
United States since 2019. And so we we
went through pretty extensive efforts to
make this as accessible as we as we
could um while still being compliant
with relevant rules and regulations. Um
one of the things that we were able to
do that I most sales have not been able
to do is if you're outside the US um you
know we have locks that are the minimum
required in your jurisdiction. For the
United States that is a one-year lock.
Okay. Um this is another good question.
Bandwidth Bob fiber optics costs
millions. How will you on board small
infrastructure providers who lack the
capital to participate?
So it depends. I I I guess I'm not
exactly sure which small infrastructure
providers would have fiber but not the
capital for like the zero contribution
is very small cost compared to the cost
of actually putting in fiber. But we
work with small data centers that are
interested in like basically delivering
d0ero services to validators operating
within them. And so the way that that
works is you basically bookend each leg
of a piece of fiber with a0ero device
which is a switch. Uh these are
commercial enterprisegrade switches. So
it's not like some hardware we've built
ourselves. Um and then that allows
validators in that data center to
connect in to the0ero network. And so um
you know uh chances are any data center
already has one of these switches in it
or even quite frankly more expensive
switches than this inside of it. When it
when it comes to like increased use
of0ero where do you see this going? I
mean like is Salana and going to tap
into zero's um infrastructure. Uh what
does that look like in the next two to
five years? Yeah, I mean the answer
there is it's really up to those
networks and those validators, right?
The Salana community has largely said
and the Salana protocol developers have
said they're very interested in pushing
past the bounds of what's possible on
the public internet and double zero is a
a great way to do that. And so if you
saw uh the release of Alpenlow um you
know there's mentions to zero and
multiccast in that in that as well which
is the new Salana consensus proposal.
Um, we've had lots of conversations with
L2s and other L1s about um, you know,
coming on board and and joining the zero
network, but at the end of the day, no
one can force the validators to adopt
0ero. They have to evaluate it for
themselves, see if it's going to be
something that makes them more money,
and see if the community is interested
in pushing past what's possible on the
public internet. Um, but the expansion
areas for D0ero are even outside of
crypto as well. You can have storage
networks either cryptographic storage
networks or non-cryptographic storage
networks, CDNs, um, AI workloads and
training data that has to be moved
around. The there's a whole series of
companies, most companies you've heard
of that are software companies run their
own private networks today. Um, and many
of them may find D0ero to be an
attractive alternative. One thing to
remember is there's no prioritization on
the public internet. You would think
that Epic Games can just pay a priority
fee. So all the Fortnite data is
prioritized and kids can have good
gaming experiences. That's not part of
the internet spec. Just get in line with
everyone else. We're going to wrap it
up, but one more question here. I'm I'm
not quite sure how accurate this is. So
it's from Max Wrestellin. After the
Salana test net, you plan multi-chain
support. Why not wait until fiber works
on Bitcoin or L1's before scaling out?
That's I I I don't know. Yeah, you might
be able to. I'm not quite sure what
they're what they're asking. um you
know, Bitcoin and the Ethereum L1 are
not going to benefit from D0ero because
they're not networks that are built to
op like where speed and latency actually
matter. And so the question to ask
yourself if you're looking at could
double help this blockchain or this
application is is there a capacity
question where if you get more bandwidth
things get better or a system where if
latency is reduced performance or value
increases. Now, this is true in Tradfi.
If you've read Flash Boys, like that's
the name of the game, right? Bitcoin is
not designed for that. Bitcoin is
designed to be slow. The Ethereum L1 is
designed to be slow. And until changes
are made to that protocol, there's
really no uh reason someone would opt to
use zero, I don't think. What about
Lightning? I mean, uh certainly. Yeah.
Uh Bitcoin L2s and whatever we qualify
Lightning as nowadays, uh those are
systems where speed and performance
really matter, unlike the Bitcoin L1.
All right, Austin, thank you very much
for your time. Thank you to you watching
for all your thoughtful questions. It's
really great to see you doing something
new and exciting. Um, I think it's
always interesting to hear about
infrastructure players as well and not
not just more of the same kind of stuff
and I think that you are really trying
to prove uh or solve something that is a
perplexing problem for a lot of
infrastructure and blockchains and
different distributed networks. So, it's
been great to catch up with you again.
Thank you very much for watching the
live stream. and we will be back uh in
about 30 minutes or so with our next
couple of interviews. Um catch us then.
We're here live at Proof of Work. Thank
you very much for watching.
[Music]

cleanText:
Hello everyone. Welcome back to
Cointelegraph's live stream right here
at Proof of Talk in Paris. It's been
a fantastic two days here at this
conference, a conference that came
around last year and really made waves
for the high-profile speakers that they
have and the really great programming
and venue right here in the heart of
Paris at the Louv. I'm joined today
by a man that I know quite well. We've
spoken on many occasions, always to
do with Solana. Austin Federa, it's
great to have you on the live stream.
Before we get started, if you have any
questions for Austin, please drop them
in the comments right here on X or
YouTube, whatever platform you're
watching on, go ahead, fire them away.
We'll pose them to Austin.
He can say yes or no. You have free
will. But it's good to see you again,
man, and in very different
circumstances. I don't want to talk too
much about Solana, but I've never asked
you since you left. Tell us the story
why you left Solana and what your
general experience was there and the
story behind that. Yeah, well
thanks for having me. I mean I was with
Solana for four years. When I joined,
there were, I think, 30 daily active
programs on the network, and no one
really knew what Solana was. It was very
much an underdog. And then, you know,
you fast forward four years later, and
the network is one of the most dominant
networks out there. It is the highest
revenue generation network in crypto. It's
in an incredible place. But I
kind of always had a little bit of that
itch to go be a founder, and at the same
time, I really didn't want to go build
something that was competitive with
Solana or build something that was on
top of Solana, right? It was really
like a challenge to think of what are
the types of applications you can build
that will really move crypto forwards a
decade and two years. How do we really
get into this place?
We've talked about mainstream adoption
and taking on TradFi forever, but the
fundamental core infrastructure isn't
there. And so the real moment for me to
say Double Zero is worth building and
there's a market here that's worth
addressing was working on the Fire
Dancer project and seeing the fact that
we had engineers working on this project
that could build a validator client that
could do a million transactions per
second, but they couldn't run it on the
public internet. The public internet was

Um so there is a token for Double Zero. Um and that token is really integral to aligning incentives and functionality of the network. So validators and RPCs and other sort of users of the network on that perspective pay to operate on it. Okay. Those rewards um are paid in the Double Zero token. They're distributed out to bandwidth contributors, resource providers, and then you know a portion of those fees are also burned um on the network as well as a civil resistance mechanism. The really interesting piece is most of the criticisms of proof of stake and deepen networks are that they reward basically passive existence and our model doesn't do that. We actually published a blog post a few days ago called proof of utility. And really the model here is we reward useful connectivity and we reward it only from the reward pool that's coming in from users of the network. So we don't have crazy inflation on the network. We don't have sort of passive existence rewards. It's a similar model to proof of work in Bitcoin where if you produce 50% of the hash power, you will over an average period of time get 50% of the rewards. If you provide the most useful network connectivity pathway that reaches the most stake, you are going to be rewarded proportionally for that.
